text: RTC is a New Zealand record label which licensed recordings from overseas Independent labels in the United States and in the United Kingdom. ==Background== The label was started in the late 1970s by John McCready, Brian Pitts, and Warwick Woodward.Audio Culture 4 May 2016 John McCready part 3 - the CBS years - Murray CammickAudio Culture 19 May 2016 John McCready Profile Murray Cammick While still a fledgling indie distributor, they had Kama Fitzgerald in their employ who had previously worked for PolyGram marketing manager Stuart Rubin.Audio Culture 21 May 2014 RipItUp - Murray Cammick In 1980, it was reported by Phil Gifford in the October 11 issue of Billboard that as an independent NZ label they had made a first. With the artists on their label having both an album and single at no 1 on the NZ charts, it was the first time an Independent label in New Zealand had achieved this. The album at the top of the charts was Black Sea by XTC, and the single was "Food For Thought" by UB 40.Billboard October 11, 1980 Page 58 International, _New Zealand Success_ , Indi RTC Bucks $ Slump With LP And Single Clicks - By Phil Gifford In 1981, it was reported by Glenn A. Baker in the September 19 edition of Billboard that the Australian Liberation label was sub-licensing recordings to RTC. However one act Mink DeVille, was to be excluded and instead be given to WEA New Zealand, due to its managing director Tim Murdoch having a personal interest in the band.Billboard September 19, 1981 Page 72 International , Australian New Music Liberation Label Bows By Glenn A. Baker In 1982, the label's way they packaged limited edition albums and singles worked well. In a week, the limited edition 7 inch picture sleeves of the groups Heaven 17 and were sold out.Billboard, June 12, 1982 A/NZ - 16 New Zealanders ===Staff=== As of 1979, the managing director of the label was Brian Pitts. The Promotions manager was Kama Fitzgerald.Billboard December 1, 1979 Page 46, International, Virgin Acts, New Zealand Package For U.K. Outlets - By Phil Gifford ==New Zealand artists== ===Kevin Blackatini & the Frigids=== Kevin Blackatini And The Frigids were an outfit that had a novelty hit in 1981 with "The Fridge", which was a parody of "The Bridge" which was previously a hit Deane Waretini. Kevin Blackatini was actually Kevin Black from Auckland radio station, Radio Hauraki.45cat Record Details, Artist: Kevin Blackatini And The FrigidsNZ On Screen Kevin Blackatini and the Frigids ===Gary Havoc & The Hurricanes=== Auckland band, Gary Havoc & The Hurricanes, had an EP/mini-album issued on the label in 1979,National Library of New Zealand Gary Havoc & the Hurricanes (sound recording)Discogs Gary Havoc & The Hurricanes – Havoc! The credited musicians on the recording were Havoc on guitar and vocals, John Treseder on lead guitar, Gavin Beardsmore on bass, and Graeme Scott on drums.Discogs Gary Havoc & The Hurricanes – Havoc! Drummer Gary Hunt had left to join the Terrorways.All Music Terrorways Artist Biography by Jason Ankeny According to John Dix, in his book Stranded in Paradise: New Zealand Rock'n'Roll, 1955-1988, the group have noted as being responsible for being one of the first, if not the first New Zealand band to self-finance their record and be successful with it, which had a flow on effect for other bands.Stranded in Paradise: New Zealand Rock'n'roll, 1955-1988, by John Dix, Page 219, Page 294 They received an IRANZ award for their EP.Kiwi Concert Date Archive Saturday, June 18, 2011 Gary Havoc and the Hurricanes In the mid 1980s, Havoc teamed up with singer / keyboardist Suzie Divine, calling themselves Desire. They released a record on WEA in 1985 which featured Mark Huckstep and Robbie Robertson on bass and Simon Hannah and Mark Hansen on drums.Elsewhere Jul 30, 2014 Desire: Broken Heart (1985Gary Havoc website Gary Havoc Gallery 1 ==International artists== Some of the international artists marketed by the label include Ian Matthews whose single "Shake It" RTC RTS 701 had climbed from no 28 to 19.45cat Record Details, Catalogue: RTS 701Billboard March 17, 1979 Page 95 Billboard Hits Of The World, New Zealand Others include Joy Division.Billboard 12 June 1982 A/NZ-16 New Zealanders, Radio ==Releases (selective)== ===7" singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" |+ Singles |- !
